section.title: Introduction
section.t: In-situ Operations, Administration, and Maintenance (IOAM) records operational and telemetry information in the packet while the packet traverses a path between two points in the network. This document outlines how IOAM data fields are encapsulated in the IPv4 .

section.title: In-situ OAM Metadata Transport in IPv4
section.t: An IPv4 option is defined corresponding to each of the IOAM data fields defined in . These mechanisms of in-situ OAM in IPv4 are used to enhance diagnostics of IPv4 networks. IOAM is carried in IPv4 packets as a new single option, with an option type identifier TBD_IOAM that will be defined by IANA, and according to the options definition in . While specifying a new option to carry IOAM data, one may see this as an extension to the already defined "record route" and "internet timestamp" options in , which allows a packet to record its route and collect timestamps throughout the network. The various IOAM data fields defined in [I-D.ietf-ippm-ioam-data] are added as TLVs within the new IPv4 option. In an administrative domain where IOAM is used, insertion of the IOAM header in IPv4 is enabled at the IOAM domain edge, which serve as IOAM encapsulating/decapsulating nodes by means of configuration.

section.title: Considerations for in-situ OAM in IPv4 options
section.t: In the scope of IPv4 header and its options in , there are unique considerations for embedding in-situ OAM in the IPv4 options.

section.title: Alignment
section.t: Within an IPv4 options stack there is no requirement for alignment outside the octet granularity, which doesn't limit the granularity of the in-situ OAM, since it is already 4-octects aligned.

section.title: Total available length
section.t:
There are three fields that may affect the total available length for in-situ OAM data to be incorporated in the IPv4 options: The IPv4 header's IHL, as described in in section 3.1: This 4-bit field can reach up to 15 times 4 octets, including the IPv4 header, which is 20 octets. This leaves a maximum actual length of 40 octets to the options. Reducing 4 octets for the use of the option's header, it leaves 36 octets for the use of the in-situ OAM data. In the context of the trace type, which has an 8 octets header, this leaves 28 bytes for actual data to be collected during the packet's traverse through the network.
The option's length, as described here above in section 3: This 8-bit field can reach up to 255 octets. Doesn't further restrict the in-situ OAM length, because of the above restrictions that are already applied.
Datagram's Total length, as described in in section 3.1: Doesn't further restrict the in-situ OAM length, because of the above restrictions that are already applied.

section.title: Pre-allocation vs. Incremental trace types
section.t:
Considering the IPv4 architecture, and specifically the "record route" and "internet timestamp" options definitions, the RFC calls for "The size of the option does not change due to adding addresses...", and similarly for the timestamp option. Hence, while incorporating In-situ OAM trace type header, an implementation SHOULD use one of these two techniques: Immediate Export mode, controlled by the I-bit as part of the trace flags.
Pre-allocated trace type as described in section 4.1.1 of .

section.title: IP checksum
section.t: IPv4 Header Checksum, as described in MUST be recalculated by a device that is updating the In-situ OAM IPv4 option.

section.title: TCP checksum
section.t: TCP's pseudo header, as described in , doesn't include neither the IPv4 options nor the IHL, hence doesn't need to be recalculated by a device that is adding, removing or updating the in-situ OAM IPv4 option.

section.title: UDP checksum
section.t: UDP's pseudo header, as described in , doesn't include neither the IPv4 options nor the IHL, hence doesn't need to be recalculated by a device that is adding, removing or updating the in-situ OAM IPv4 option.

section.title: Fragmentation
section.t: Considering the IPv4 architecture, and specifically the "record route" and "internet timestamp" options definitions, is calling for setting the option's copy to zero, hence "Not copied on fragmentation, goes in first fragment only". It seems reasonable to the authors to keep this idea to prevent duplication of route data and maintain similar behavior for the operator, hence an implementer SHOULD follow this method.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: This document describes the encapsulation of IOAM data fields in IPv4. Security considerations of the specific IOAM data fields for each case (i.e., Trace, Proof of Transit, and E2E) are described in defined in .
As this document describes a new option for IPv4, that is similar in their behavior to an already existing options, the security considerations are similar as well to those of .
